content.text:
# List of Intangible Cultural Heritage elements in Oman

]]
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) intangible cultural heritage elements are the non-physical traditions and practices performed by a people. As part of a country's cultural heritage, they include celebrations, festivals, performances, oral traditions, music, and the making of handicrafts. The "intangible cultural heritage" is defined by the Convention for the Safeguarding of Intangible Cultural Heritage, drafted in 2003 and took effect in 2006. Inscription of new heritage elements on the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists is determined by the Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of Intangible Cultural Heritage, an organisation established by the convention.
Oman signed the convention on 4 August 2005.
Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity
Representative List
{|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders"
! style="width:25%" | Name
! class="unsortable"| Image
! Year
! No.
! class="unsortable"| Description
|-
! scope="row" | Al-Bar'ah, music and dance of Oman Dhofari valleys
|
| 2010
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-bar-ah-music-and-dance-of-oman-dhofari-valleys-00372 00372]
| ''Al-Bar'ah from the Dhofar Mountains is a dance of two or four bedouins swaying a Khanjar dagger, accompanied by drums, flute and song.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Al-Taghrooda, traditional Bedouin chanted poetry in the United Arab Emirates and the Sultanate of Oman +
|
| 2012
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-taghrooda-traditional-bedouin-chanted-poetry-in-the-united-arab-emirates-and-the-sultanate-of-oman-00744 00744]
| Al-Taghrooda'' is a camel rider's song of seven verses, performed in two antiphonal groups.
|-
! scope="row" | Al 'azi, elegy, processional march and poetry
|
| 2012
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-azi-elegy-processional-march-and-poetry-00850 00850]
| ''Al 'azi is performed solo by a lead singer brandishing a sword. The group following him replies with single notes.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Al-Ayyala, a traditional performing art of the Sultanate of Oman and the United Arab Emirates +
|
| 2014
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-ayyala-a-traditional-performing-art-of-the-sultanate-of-oman-and-the-united-arab-emirates-01012 01012]
| Al-Ayyala is a weapon dance traditionally performed during weddings, celebrations, and other events.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Majlis, a cultural and social space +
|
| 2015
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/majlis-a-cultural-and-social-space-01076 01076]
| Majlis'' –meaning "sitting room"– is a meeting place for society's individuals to debate matters and local issues, and exchanging news whether public affairs news or what concern the attendees.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Arabic coffee, a symbol of generosity +
|
| 2015
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/arabic-coffee-a-symbol-of-generosity-02111 02111]
| Serving qahwa is an important part of hospitality. It is prepared in front of the guests, starting with roasting the beans. It is bitter and served without sugar.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Al-Razfa, a traditional performing art +
|
| 2015
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-razfa-a-traditional-performing-art-01078 01078]
| Between two rows of men with symbolic rifles is room for dancers, accompanied by antiphonal singing.
|-
! scope="row" | Horse and camel Ardhah
|
| 2018
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/horse-and-camel-ardhah-01359 01359]
| ardhah is the art of instructing a horse or camel for work. It is frequently presented at Alardha festivals.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Camel racing, a social practice and a festive heritage associated with camels +
|
| 2020
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/camel-racing-a-social-practice-and-a-festive-heritage-associated-with-camels-01576 01576]
|
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Arabic calligraphy: knowledge, skills and practices +
|
| 2021
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/arabic-calligraphy-knowledge-skills-and-practices-01718 01718]
| The artistic practice of writing Arabic letters and words to convey grace and beauty.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Alheda'a, oral traditions of calling camel flocks +
|
| 2022
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/alheda-a-oral-traditions-of-calling-camel-flocks-01717 01717]
| Alheda'a is an oral tradition of calling a flock of camels passed on through generations.
|-
! scope="row" | Al-Khanjar, craft skills and social practices
|
| 2022
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/al-khanjar-craft-skills-and-social-practices-01844 01844]
| A khanjar is a traditional dagger worn by men for ceremonial occasions, it is a short curved blade shaped like the letter "J" and resembles a hook.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Date palm, knowledge, skills, traditions and practices +
|
| 2022
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/date-palm-knowledge-skills-traditions-and-practices-01902 01902]
| The Palm tree is considered to be a part of the history of the countries where it is a source for farmers, craftsmen, handicrafts owners, merchants, factory owners and food companies.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Harees dish: know-how, skills and practices +
|
| 2023
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/harees-dish-know-how-skills-and-practices-01744 01744]
| Harees, is a dish of boiled, cracked, or coarsely-ground cracked wheat or bulgur, mixed with meat and seasoned.
|-
! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| Henna, rituals, aesthetic and social practices +
|
| 2024
| [https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/henna-rituals-aesthetic-and-social-practices-02116 02116]
|A temporary tattooing practice with medicinal and aesthetic motivations.
|}
